<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPORTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/09/nfl-shrouded-uncertainty-returns?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Are We Ready for Some Football?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Football in stitches " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMzYyL2Zvb3RiYWxsX2luX3N0aXRjaGVzLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As the Kansas City Chiefs and the Houston Texans <a href="https://news.yahoo.com/covid-cloud-over-nfl-season-021624288.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">kick off</a> the NFL season tonight, some things will be different, like Tom Brady in a Bucs uniform, and some things will stay the same, like tailgating then not going into the stadium. Here’s the state of football in 2020.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">It’s still a money-making machine</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If the NFL were a tech company, reports of stable year-over-year revenue would send shares tumbling. In the 2020 entertainment biz? That’s a huge win. Sportico reports <a href="https://www.sportico.com/business/media/2020/nfl-ad-sales-running-hot-despite-uncertainty-1234612696/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ad spend</a> is “effectively in lockstep with last season’s pace,” showing that not even a pandemic can slow marketers’ appetite for the NFL’s massive audience.  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Also helping: </strong></span><span>The league’s most prolific spenders last year—Amazon, Verizon, Procter & Gamble, GM, Apple, Progressive, State Farm, and others—weathered the pandemic better than most.  </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s also the only pigskin game in town. 41% of college football’s FBS schools won’t be playing in the fall, setting up the NFL for potentially historic TV ratings. On the flip side, it has to contend with the NBA (and NHL) playoffs for the first time ever.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Testing is negative</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Which is a positive. Last month, news of 77 positive coronavirus tests threw the league a curveball...until it was discovered all 77 were false-positives. More recent numbers have been Joe Burrow-level promising—<a href="https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/29838540/one-nfl-player-positive-covid-19-result-latest-testing-period?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">only one</a> NFL player returned a positive result in the latest testing period. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>To monitor any potential spread of the virus, every player and essential team employee will be tested daily (except for game days). </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The other big safety concern stems from fans. So far, <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/is-it-safe-to-go-to-a-live-sporting-event-these-nfl-teams-say-yes-11599143591?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">only seven teams</a>, including the Chiefs, have agreed to let fans attend games at a reduced capacity. But many other organizations have left the door open as the season progresses. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>The NBA bubble set the standard for sports leagues returning to action, but the financial heft and influence of the NFL will show us whether pandemic-era sports can work on a grander scale. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
LUXURY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/09/lvmh-tiffany-deal-collapsing?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Why the LVMH/Tiffany Deal Is Collapsing
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="LVMH and Tiffany " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMjE5L2x2bWhfYW5kX3RpZmZhbnkuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Whenever you see the word “Delaware” in a story about the largest luxury deal ever, you know something has gone terribly wrong.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, U.S. jeweler Tiffany sued French luxury giant LVMH in Delaware after LVMH tried to <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/09/lvmh-scraps-16point2-billion-deal-with-tiffany.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">back out</a> of its $16.2 billion acquisition of Tiffany. The dustup started with a letter the French government sent to LVMH requesting that it delay the takeover until January 6, 2021. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why delay? </strong>France wants to sort out a <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/lvmh-pulls-out-of-tiffany-takeover-11599649473?mod=hp_lead_pos2&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">trade dispute</a> with the Trump administration.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The U.S. claims France’s proposed tax on digital companies unfairly targets American firms like Google and Facebook.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In response, the U.S. has threatened tariffs on French goods, including makeup and handbags. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Tiffany thinks LVMH is using the letter as an excuse to get out of a deal it regrets signing. It has a point—the pandemic devastated the luxury industry and, per recent reports, LVMH CEO Bernard Arnault was already looking to hit the “<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/04/lvmh-reportedly-trying-renegotiate-tiffany-acquisition.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">cancel order</a>” button. LVMH says France’s request puts the situation entirely out of its hands.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>lawyers.</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
DIVERSITY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/09/board-challenge-launches-increase-representation-among-company-directors?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Are You Taking The Board Challenge?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Nike, Gap, Levi's missing diverse talent in corporate roles" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNDIzL2VtcHR5X2NvbmZlcmVuY2Vfcm9vbS5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A new initiative launched yesterday to change the look of American boardrooms—specifically, to make them look less white. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Board Challenge, a project of Altimeter Capital, Valence, and theBoardlist, is <a href="https://www.fastcompany.com/90548491/these-17-companies-are-pledging-to-add-a-black-board-member-by-the-end-of-2021?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">challenging</a> U.S. firms to add a Black director to their boards within 12 months. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>17 companies, including Zillow and Nextdoor, have </span><span><a href="https://theboardchallenge.org/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">taken the pledge</a></span><span>. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Another 27 members with at least one Black board member (United Airlines, Nordstrom among them) are working with the project to advance diversity efforts. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why it’s an issue: </strong>9% of Fortune 500 board members are Black men and women, while 66% are white men and 18% are white women, according to theBoardlist—and Black representation on boards hasn’t budged in the last few years. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Some states, like <a href="https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-08-30/california-corporations-diversify-boards-directors-legislature?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">California</a> most recently, have introduced legislation that would require, not just “challenge,” publicly held companies to appoint at least one director from an underrepresented community by the end of 2021.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>It’s <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/zillow-nextdoor-and-other-companies-pledge-to-add-black-directors-11599649200?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">notoriously difficult</a> for newcomers to find a seat in the boardroom. 72% of directors have previous board experience and half are current or ex-CEOs, per Heidrick & Struggles.</p>

<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/09/nyc-restaurants-allowed-reopen-indoor-dining-september-30?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Responses to the Sentence, “You Can Eat Indoors at NYC Restaurants”
</font></a>
</h1>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">September 2019: </strong>Yeah, we know...very odd of you to say that. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">September 2020: </strong>OMG are you serious???????</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Whatever your reaction, it’s actually happening: NY Governor Andrew Cuomo will allow <a href="https://twitter.com/NYGovCuomo/status/1303744894658371587?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">indoor dining</a> in New York City on Sept. 30 after six months of closures. Of course, this being a pandemic and all, the dining experience won’t be typical:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Restaurants will be capped at 25% capacity.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Diners must get their temperature checked at the door, and one member of the party must provide information for contact tracing purposes.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>New York City’s restaurants aren’t exactly known for social distancing—it’s not uncommon to take a bite of your neighbor’s sea bass thinking it’s your own. But for desperate restaurateurs that have <a href="https://ny.eater.com/2020/8/24/21399599/nyc-mayor-bill-de-blasio-indoor-dining-comments?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">lobbied the city</a> to reopen indoor dining spaces, any step inside is a big step. Nearly 10,000 restaurants set up outdoor seating since July, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/23/nyregion/outdoor-dining-new-york.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">writes the NYT</a>, and the prospect of dropping temperatures makes everyone in the industry shiver.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>Cuomo will make a decision about 50% capacity by Nov. 1.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MARKETS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/09/new-stock-exchanges-aim-rethink-exchanges-entirely?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Exchanges Are A-Changin'
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="New York Stock Exchange" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=379 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/Wd58UQLClejZe/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="New York Stock Exchange" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/Wd58UQLClejZe/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">With equity volume up about 50% over last year, new stock exchanges are <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/09/a-spate-of-new-stock-exchanges-are-ready-to-launch-that-want-to-compete-for-your-trading-dollar.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">popping up</a> to snag a slice of the hundreds of billions of dollars traded on the stock market each day.  </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Say hello to...</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The Members Exchange</strong>, set to launch its "Phase One" on September 21, is backed by basically everyone on Wall Street, including banks JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs, money managers like BlackRock and Fidelity, and online brokers Charles Schwab and TD Ameritrade. In a classic case of “I could totally do this for cheaper,” the coalition aims to undercut the traditional players on fees.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The Long-Term Stock Exchange</strong>, which launched yesterday, hopes to recruit companies that are less focused on <a href="https://longtermstockexchange.com/listings/principles/?campaign_id=4&emc=edit_dk_20200909&instance_id=22027&nl=dealbook&regi_id=83342785&segment_id=37666&te=1&user_id=6e8f5c5256f51c870f4df90ca819260d&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">short-term results</a> and more interested in “long-term value creation,” diversity and inclusion, and the environment. “The goal [of the other exchanges] is to maximize trading revenue,” CEO Eric Ries told CNBC. “This is for companies who can get held to a higher standard.” </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Incumbent exchanges are shrugging it off. Three companies—Intercontinental Exchange, Nasdaq, and Cboe—control 97% of on-exchange flow, Members Exchange CEO Jonathan Kellner told CNBC. Still, Blockbuster probably controlled 97% of the market at one point...</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FROM THE CREW
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Brew's Bookshelf
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="books" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC82ODIvYnJld19zX2Jvb2tzaGVsZi5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Every other Thursday, <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/extras/bookshelf?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Brew’s Bookshelf</a> brings you a few of our favorite, business-related reads. This week, we’re talking money: What is it, how to use it, and why you’ve been thinking about it wrong all these years. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><a href="https://bookshop.org/books/the-psychology-of-money-timeless-lessons-on-wealth-greed-and-happiness/9780857197689?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>The Psychology of Money</em></a></span><span> is a brand new book from Morgan Housel, a former WSJ columnist and partner at Collaborative Fund. He offers 19 short stories that explore how people think about money.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><a href="https://bookshop.org/books/the-ascent-of-money-a-financial-history-of-the-world-10th-anniversary-edition/9780143116172?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>The Ascent of Money</em></a></span><span> by historian Niall Ferguson travels from ancient Mesopotamia to 21st-century crypto wallets to show how money, credit, and finance have evolved throughout history. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>

width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMzYyL2Zvb3RiYWxsX2luX3N0aXRjaGVzLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs the Kansas City Chiefs and the Houston Texans \u003ca href=\"https://news.yahoo.com/covid-cloud-over-nfl-season-021624288.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ekick off\u003c/a\u003e the NFL season tonight, some things will be different, like Tom Brady in a Bucs uniform, and some things will stay the same, like tailgating then not going into the stadium. Here’s the state of football in 2020.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIt’s still a money-making machine\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf the NFL were a tech company, reports of stable year-over-year revenue would send shares tumbling. In the 2020 entertainment biz? That’s a huge win. Sportico reports \u003ca href=\"https://www.sportico.com/business/media/2020/nfl-ad-sales-running-hot-despite-uncertainty-1234612696/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ead spend\u003c/a\u003e is “effectively in lockstep with last season’s pace,” showing that not even a pandemic can slow marketers’ appetite for the NFL’s massive audience.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAlso helping: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe league’s most prolific spenders last year—Amazon, Verizon, Procter \u0026 Gamble, GM, Apple, Progressive, State Farm, and others—weathered the pandemic better than most.  \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt’s also the only pigskin game in town. 41% of college football’s FBS schools won’t be playing in the fall, setting up the NFL for potentially historic TV ratings. On the flip side, it has to contend with the NBA (and NHL) playoffs for the first time ever.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eTesting is negative\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhich is a positive. Last month, news of 77 positive coronavirus tests threw the league a curveball...until it was discovered all 77 were false-positives. More recent numbers have been Joe Burrow-level promising—\u003ca href=\"https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/29838540/one-nfl-player-positive-covid-19-result-latest-testing-period?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eonly one\u003c/a\u003e NFL player returned a positive result in the latest testing period. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eTo monitor any potential spread of the virus, every player and essential team employee will be tested daily (except for game days). \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe other big safety concern stems from fans. So far, \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/is-it-safe-to-go-to-a-live-sporting-event-these-nfl-teams-say-yes-11599143591?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eonly seven teams\u003c/a\u003e, including the Chiefs, have agreed to let fans attend games at a reduced capacity. But many other organizations have left the door open as the season progresses. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eThe NBA bubble set the standard for sports leagues returning to action, but the financial heft and influence of the NFL will show us whether pandemic-era sports can work on a grander scale. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nWhy the LVMH/Tiffany Deal Is Collapsing\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"LVMH and Tiffany \" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMjE5L2x2bWhfYW5kX3RpZmZhbnkuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhenever you see the word “Delaware” in a story about the largest luxury deal ever, you know something has gone terribly wrong.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, U.S. jeweler Tiffany sued French luxury giant LVMH in Delaware after LVMH tried to \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/09/lvmh-scraps-16point2-billion-deal-with-tiffany.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eback out\u003c/a\u003e of its $16.2 billion acquisition of Tiffany. The dustup started with a letter the French government sent to LVMH requesting that it delay the takeover until January 6, 2021. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy delay? \u003c/strong\u003eFrance wants to sort out a \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/lvmh-pulls-out-of-tiffany-takeover-11599649473?mod=hp_lead_pos2\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etrade dispute\u003c/a\u003e with the Trump administration.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe U.S. claims France’s proposed tax on digital companies unfairly targets American firms like Google and Facebook.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn response, the U.S. has threatened tariffs on French goods, including makeup and handbags. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eTiffany thinks LVMH is using the letter as an excuse to get out of a deal it regrets signing. It has a point—the pandemic devastated the luxury industry and, per recent reports, LVMH CEO Bernard Arnault was already looking to hit the “\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/04/lvmh-reportedly-trying-renegotiate-tiffany-acquisition.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecancel order\u003c/a\u003e” button. LVMH says France’s request puts the situation entirely out of its hands.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eA new initiative launched yesterday to change the look of American boardrooms—specifically, to make them look less white. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Board Challenge, a project of Altimeter Capital, Valence, and theBoardlist, is \u003ca href=\"https://www.fastcompany.com/90548491/these-17-companies-are-pledging-to-add-a-black-board-member-by-the-end-of-2021?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003echallenging\u003c/a\u003e U.S. firms to add a Black director to their boards within 12 months. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e17 companies, including Zillow and Nextdoor, have \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://theboardchallenge.org/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etaken the pledge\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAnother 27 members with at least one Black board member (United Airlines, Nordstrom among them) are working with the project to advance diversity efforts. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy it’s an issue: \u003c/strong\u003e9% of Fortune 500 board members are Black men and women, while 66% are white men and 18% are white women, according to theBoardlist—and Black representation on boards hasn’t budged in the last few years. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSome states, like \u003ca href=\"https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-08-30/california-corporations-diversify-boards-directors-legislature?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eCalifornia\u003c/a\u003e most recently, have introduced legislation that would require, not just “challenge,” publicly held companies to appoint at least one director from an underrepresented community by the end of 2021.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eIt’s \u003ca style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enotoriously difficult\u003c/a\u003e for newcomers to find a seat in the boardroom. 72% of directors have previous board style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSeptember 2019: \u003c/strong\u003eYeah, we know...very odd of you to say that. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSeptember 2020: \u003c/strong\u003eOMG are you serious???????\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhatever your reaction, it’s actually happening: NY Governor Andrew Cuomo will allow \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/NYGovCuomo/status/1303744894658371587?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eindoor dining\u003c/a\u003e in New York City on Sept. 30 after six months of closures. Of course, this being a pandemic and all, the dining experience won’t be typical:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eRestaurants will be capped at 25% capacity.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eDiners must get their temperature checked at the door, and one member of the party must provide information for contact tracing purposes.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eNew York City’s restaurants aren’t exactly known for social distancing—it’s not uncommon to take a bite of your neighbor’s sea bass thinking it’s your own. But for desperate restaurateurs that have \u003ca href=\"https://ny.eater.com/2020/8/24/21399599/nyc-mayor-bill-de-blasio-indoor-dining-comments?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elobbied the city\u003c/a\u003e to reopen indoor dining spaces, any step inside is a big step. Nearly 10,000 restaurants set up outdoor seating since July, \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/23/nyregion/outdoor-dining-new-york.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrites the NYT\u003c/a\u003e, and the prospect of dropping temperatures makes everyone in the industry shiver.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003eCuomo will make
